jays81 wrote:

> hi,
>
> thanks for that,
>
> i a still slightly confused though!
> This is the set up
>
> EventMgtBean contains method dispatch event e.g
>
> public void dispatchEvent(Event event){
>      handleEvent(event);
> }
>
> should i be adding extra methods to my bean to check if my event has
> reached the dispatchEvent method and test it in my test class or
> should i create a mock object
>

I read your previous post, particularly the part about

    "inside calls handleEvent(event), in a class called Handle"

to mean that handleEvent() was defined on a separate class.  That seems not
to be the case, given the code snippet above.  In this case, there's nothing
obvious to mock.

You could:

- Modify dispatchEvent() and handleEvent() to return something validating
whether the event was handled, then assert on that return value

- Set some state within the EventMgtBean indicating the event was handled,
then assert on that state

I typically use mock objects when I don't want to break encapsulation for the
object under test.  It's a subjective design decision.
